sen.j: 京都扶持衆（きょうとふちしゅう）とは、室町時代に室町幕府の征夷大将軍と直接主従関係を結んだ関東地方・東北地方の武士。
sen.e: The Kyoto Fuchishu are samurai warriors who established master-subordinate relationships with the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi Bakufu (shogunate) in the Muromachi Period in the Kanto (currently, Tokyo and other six prefectures) and Tohoku (north of the Kanto region) regions.

sen.j: 室町時代の関東地方は、鎌倉公方と呼ばれる征夷大将軍の代理人が鎌倉府の長として統治した。
sen.e: In the Muromachi Period, the Kanto region was being ruled by Kamakura Kubo, who was the representative of the Seii Taishogun and acting in the capacity of the head of the Kamakura-fu.

sen.e: Virtually, the Kanto region was put under indirect ruling of the bakufu.

sen.j: このような鎌倉公方の動きを牽制するため、幕府は鎌倉公方と対立している関東や奥羽の有力武士と直接主従関係を結んだ。
sen.e: To put a brake on these Kamakura Kubo's movements, the bakufu formed the master-subordinate relationships directly with influencial samurai warriors in the Kanto and Ou area.

sen.j: これらの武士は京都扶持衆（当時の記録では京都御扶持衆）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: These samurai warriors were called Kyoto Fuchishu (according to the record of that time, called Kyoto Onfuchishu.)

sen.j: 鎌倉府の管轄国内の武士でありながら、鎌倉府に出仕する義務はなく、鎌倉公方の指揮も受けず、直接将軍の指揮下に入った。
sen.e: Although they were the samurai warriors from the province under the jurisdiction of the Kamakura Bakufu, they were not obliged to go and serve for the Kamakura-fu and were put under the direct direction/control of the shogun, not being directed by the Kamakura Kubo.

sen.e: The Muromachi Bakufu was supeficially criticizing these Fuchishu's movements, but actually, providing various mental and material support to them.

sen.j: 実際に京都扶持衆となったのは、甲斐国武田氏、常陸国山入氏、小栗氏、真壁氏、大掾氏、下野国宇都宮氏、那須氏、小野寺氏、陸奥国篠川御所、伊達氏、蘆名氏、南部氏、白河結城氏などである。
sen.e: People who actually became the Kyoto Fuchishu were the Takeda clan of Kai Province, the Yamairi clan, Oguri clan, Makabe clan and Daijo clan of Hitachi Province, the Utsunomiya clan, Nasu clan and Onodera clan of Shimotsuke Province and the Sasagawa Palace, Date clan, Ashina clan, Nanbu clan and Shirakawa Yuki clan of Mutsu Province.

Individuals who actually became Kyoto Fuchishu were of the Takeda clan of Kai Province, the Yamairi clan, Oguri clan, Makabe clan and Daijo clan of Hitachi Province, the Utsunomiya clan, Nasu clan and Onodera clan of Shimotsuke Province and the Sasagawa Palace, Date clan, Ashina clan, Nanbu clan and Shirakawa Yuki clan of Mutsu Province.

sen.j: これらの家々は鎌倉公方足利持氏が元関東管領上杉禅秀に攻められた上杉禅秀の乱において、義持の禅秀討伐令を無視して禅秀を支援し、あるいは中立的態度を取った。
sen.e: When Zenshu UESUGI, former kanrei of Kanto (a shogunal deputy for the Kanto region) attacked Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, Kamakura Kubo in the War of Zenshu UESUGI, those clans supported Zenshu or maintained a neutral stance, ignoring Yoshimochi's order of putting down Zenshu.

sen.e: After the fall of Kamakura Kubo due to Eikyo no Ran, Yamanouchi-Uesugi family, kanrei of Kanto who were sympathizers of bakufu seized the power to control the Kanto, so it is believed that the Kanto Fuchishu naturally disappeared.
